string: ACT I
SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol.

The Tomb of the ANDRONICI appearing; the Tribunes  and Senators aloft. Enter, below, from one side,  SATURNINUS and his Followers; and, from the other side, BASSIANUS and his Followers; with drum and colours
SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Noble patricians, patrons of my right,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Defend the justice of my cause with arms,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And, countrymen, my loving followers,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Plead my successive title with your swords:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: I am his first-born son, that was the last
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: That wore the imperial diadem of Rome;
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Then let my father's honours live in me,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Nor wrong mine age with this indignity.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Romans, friends, followers, favorers of my right,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: If ever Bassianus, Caesar's son,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Were gracious in the eyes of royal Rome,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Keep then this passage to the Capitol
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: And suffer not dishonour to approach
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: The imperial seat, to virtue consecrate,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: To justice, continence and nobility;
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: But let desert in pure election shine,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: And, Romans, fight for freedom in your choice.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Enter MARCUS ANDRONICUS, aloft, with the crown
MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Princes, that strive by factions and by friends
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ambitiously for rule and empery,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Know that the people of Rome, for whom we stand
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: A special party, have, by common voice,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: In election for the Roman empery,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Chosen Andronicus, surnamed Pius
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: For many good and great deserts to Rome:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: A nobler man, a braver warrior,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lives not this day within the city walls:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: He by the senate is accit'd home
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: From weary wars against the barbarous Goths;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That, with his sons, a terror to our foes,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hath yoked a nation strong, train'd up in arms.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ten years are spent since first he undertook
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: This cause of Rome and chastised with arms
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Our enemies' pride: five times he hath return'd
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Bleeding to Rome, bearing his valiant sons
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: In coffins from the field;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And now at last, laden with horror's spoils,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Returns the good Andronicus to Rome,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Renowned Titus, flourishing in arms.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Let us entreat, by honour of his name,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Whom worthily you would have now succeed.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And in the Capitol and senate's right,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Whom you pretend to honour and adore,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That you withdraw you and abate your strength;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Dismiss your followers and, as suitors should,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Plead your deserts in peace and humbleness.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: How fair the tribune speaks to calm my thoughts!
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Marcus Andronicus, so I do ally
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: In thy uprightness and integrity,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: And so I love and honour thee and thine,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Thy noble brother Titus and his sons,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: And her to whom my thoughts are humbled all,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Gracious Lavinia, Rome's rich ornament,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: That I will here dismiss my loving friends,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: And to my fortunes and the people's favor
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Commit my cause in balance to be weigh'd.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Exeunt the followers of BASSIANUS
SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Friends, that have been thus forward in my right,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: I thank you all and here dismiss you all,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And to the love and favor of my country
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Commit myself, my person and the cause.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Exeunt the followers of SATURNINUS
Rome, be as just and gracious unto me
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: As I am confident and kind to thee.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Open the gates, and let me in.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Tribunes, and me, a poor competitor.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Flourish. SATURNINUS and BASSIANUS go up into the Capitol
Enter a Captain
Captain
speaker: Captain

string: Romans, make way: the good Andronicus.
speaker: Captain

string: Patron of virtue, Rome's best champion,
speaker: Captain

string: Successful in the battles that he fights,
speaker: Captain

string: With honour and with fortune is return'd
speaker: Captain

string: From where he circumscribed with his sword,
speaker: Captain

string: And brought to yoke, the enemies of Rome.
speaker: Captain

string: Drums and trumpets sounded. Enter MARTIUS and  MUTIUS; After them, two Men bearing a coffin  covered with black; then LUCIUS and QUINTUS. After  them, TITUS ANDRONICUS; and then TAMORA, with  ALARBUS, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, AARON, and other Goths,  prisoners; Soldiers and people following. The Bearers set down the coffin, and TITUS speaks
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hail, Rome, victorious in thy mourning weeds!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lo, as the bark, that hath discharged her fraught,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Returns with precious jading to the bay
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: From whence at first she weigh'd her anchorage,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Cometh Andronicus, bound with laurel boughs,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To re-salute his country with his tears,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tears of true joy for his return to Rome.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou great defender of this Capitol,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Stand gracious to the rites that we intend!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Romans, of five and twenty valiant sons,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Half of the number that King Priam had,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Behold the poor remains, alive and dead!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: These that survive let Rome reward with love;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: These that I bring unto their latest home,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: With burial amongst their ancestors:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Here Goths have given me leave to sheathe my sword.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Titus, unkind and careless of thine own,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why suffer'st thou thy sons, unburied yet,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To hover on the dreadful shore of Styx?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Make way to lay them by their brethren.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The tomb is opened
There greet in silence, as the dead are wont,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And sleep in peace, slain in your country's wars!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O sacred receptacle of my joys,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Sweet cell of virtue and nobility,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: How many sons of mine hast thou in store,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That thou wilt never render to me more!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Give us the proudest prisoner of the Goths,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That we may hew his limbs, and on a pile
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Ad manes fratrum sacrifice his flesh,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Before this earthy prison of their bones;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That so the shadows be not unappeased,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Nor we disturb'd with prodigies on earth.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I give him you, the noblest that survives,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The eldest son of this distressed queen.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Stay, Roman brethren! Gracious conqueror,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Victorious Titus, rue the tears I shed,
speaker: TAMORA

string: A mother's tears in passion for her son:
speaker: TAMORA

string: And if thy sons were ever dear to thee,
speaker: TAMORA

string: O, think my son to be as dear to me!
speaker: TAMORA

string: Sufficeth not that we are brought to Rome,
speaker: TAMORA

string: To beautify thy triumphs and return,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Captive to thee and to thy Roman yoke,
speaker: TAMORA

string: But must my sons be slaughter'd in the streets,
speaker: TAMORA

string: For valiant doings in their country's cause?
speaker: TAMORA

string: O, if to fight for king and commonweal
speaker: TAMORA

string: Were piety in thine, it is in these.
speaker: TAMORA

string: Andronicus, stain not thy tomb with blood:
speaker: TAMORA

string: Wilt thou draw near the nature of the gods?
speaker: TAMORA

string: Draw near them then in being merciful:
speaker: TAMORA

string: Sweet mercy is nobility's true badge:
speaker: TAMORA

string: Thrice noble Titus, spare my first-born son.
speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Patient yourself, madam, and pardon me.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: These are their brethren, whom you Goths beheld
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Alive and dead, and for their brethren slain
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Religiously they ask a sacrifice:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To this your son is mark'd, and die he must,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To appease their groaning shadows that are gone.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Away with him! and make a fire straight;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And with our swords, upon a pile of wood,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Let's hew his limbs till they be clean consumed.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Exeunt LUCIUS, QUINTUS, MARTIUS, and MUTIUS, with ALARBUS
TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: O cruel, irreligious piety!
speaker: TAMORA

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Was ever Scythia half so barbarous?
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Oppose not Scythia to ambitious Rome.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Alarbus goes to rest; and we survive
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: To tremble under Titus' threatening looks.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Then, madam, stand resolved, but hope withal
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: The self-same gods that arm'd the Queen of Troy
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: With opportunity of sharp revenge
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Upon the Thracian tyrant in his tent,
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: May favor Tamora, the Queen of Goths--
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: When Goths were Goths and Tamora was queen--
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: To quit the bloody wrongs upon her foes.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Re-enter LUCIUS, QUINTUS, MARTIUS and MUTIUS, with their swords bloody
LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: See, lord and father, how we have perform'd
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Our Roman rites: Alarbus' limbs are lopp'd,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And entrails feed the sacrificing fire,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Whose smoke, like incense, doth perfume the sky.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Remaineth nought, but to inter our brethren,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And with loud 'larums welcome them to Rome.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Let it be so; and let Andronicus
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Make this his latest farewell to their souls.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Trumpets sounded, and the coffin laid in the tomb
In peace and honour rest you here, my sons;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Rome's readiest champions, repose you here in rest,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Secure from worldly chances and mishaps!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Here lurks no treason, here no envy swells,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Here grow no damned grudges; here are no storms,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: No noise, but silence and eternal sleep:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In peace and honour rest you here, my sons!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Enter LAVINIA
LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: In peace and honour live Lord Titus long;
speaker: LAVINIA

string: My noble lord and father, live in fame!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Lo, at this tomb my tributary tears
speaker: LAVINIA

string: I render, for my brethren's obsequies;
speaker: LAVINIA

string: And at thy feet I kneel, with tears of joy,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Shed on the earth, for thy return to Rome:
speaker: LAVINIA

string: O, bless me here with thy victorious hand,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Whose fortunes Rome's best citizens applaud!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Kind Rome, that hast thus lovingly reserved
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The cordial of mine age to glad my heart!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lavinia, live; outlive thy father's days,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And fame's eternal date, for virtue's praise!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Enter, below, MARCUS ANDRONICUS and Tribunes; re-enter SATURNINUS and BASSIANUS, attended
MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Long live Lord Titus, my beloved brother,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Gracious triumpher in the eyes of Rome!
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thanks, gentle tribune, noble brother Marcus.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And welcome, nephews, from successful wars,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: You that survive, and you that sleep in fame!
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Fair lords, your fortunes are alike in all,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That in your country's service drew your swords:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: But safer triumph is this funeral pomp,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That hath aspired to Solon's happiness
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And triumphs over chance in honour's bed.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Titus Andronicus, the people of Rome,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Whose friend in justice thou hast ever been,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Send thee by me, their tribune and their trust,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: This palliament of white and spotless hue;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And name thee in election for the empire,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: With these our late-deceased emperor's sons:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Be candidatus then, and put it on,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And help to set a head on headless Rome.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: A better head her glorious body fits
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Than his that shakes for age and feebleness:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: What should I don this robe, and trouble you?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Be chosen with proclamations to-day,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To-morrow yield up rule, resign my life,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And set abroad new business for you all?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Rome, I have been thy soldier forty years,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And led my country's strength successfully,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And buried one and twenty valiant sons,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Knighted in field, slain manfully in arms,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In right and service of their noble country
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Give me a staff of honour for mine age,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But not a sceptre to control the world:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Upright he held it, lords, that held it last.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Titus, thou shalt obtain and ask the empery.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Proud and ambitious tribune, canst thou tell?
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Patience, Prince Saturninus.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Romans, do me right:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Patricians, draw your swords: and sheathe them not
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Till Saturninus be Rome's emperor.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Andronicus, would thou wert shipp'd to hell,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Rather than rob me of the people's hearts!
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Proud Saturnine, interrupter of the good
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That noble-minded Titus means to thee!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Content thee, prince; I will restore to thee
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The people's hearts, and wean them from themselves.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Andronicus, I do not flatter thee,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: But honour thee, and will do till I die:
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: My faction if thou strengthen with thy friends,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: I will most thankful be; and thanks to men
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Of noble minds is honourable meed.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: People of Rome, and people's tribunes here,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I ask your voices and your suffrages:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Will you bestow them friendly on Andronicus?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tribunes
speaker: Tribunes

string: To gratify the good Andronicus,
speaker: Tribunes

string: And gratulate his safe return to Rome,
speaker: Tribunes

string: The people will accept whom he admits.
speaker: Tribunes

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tribunes, I thank you: and this suit I make,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That you create your emperor's eldest son,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lord Saturnine; whose virtues will, I hope,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Reflect on Rome as Titan's rays on earth,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And ripen justice in this commonweal:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then, if you will elect by my advice,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Crown him and say 'Long live our emperor!'
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: With voices and applause of every sort,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Patricians and plebeians, we create
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lord Saturninus Rome's great emperor,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And say 'Long live our Emperor Saturnine!'
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: A long flourish till they come down
SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Titus Andronicus, for thy favors done
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: To us in our election this day,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: I give thee thanks in part of thy deserts,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And will with deeds requite thy gentleness:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And, for an onset, Titus, to advance
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Thy name and honourable family,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Lavinia will I make my empress,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Rome's royal mistress, mistress of my heart,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And in the sacred Pantheon her espouse:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Tell me, Andronicus, doth this motion please thee?
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: It doth, my worthy lord; and in this match
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I hold me highly honour'd of your grace:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And here in sight of Rome to Saturnine,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: King and commander of our commonweal,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The wide world's emperor, do I consecrate
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: My sword, my chariot and my prisoners;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Presents well worthy Rome's imperial lord:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Receive them then, the tribute that I owe,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Mine honour's ensigns humbled at thy feet.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Thanks, noble Titus, father of my life!
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: How proud I am of thee and of thy gifts
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Rome shall record, and when I do forget
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: The least of these unspeakable deserts,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Romans, forget your fealty to me.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: [To TAMORA]  Now, madam, are you prisoner to
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: an emperor;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To him that, for your honour and your state,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Will use you nobly and your followers.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: A goodly lady, trust me; of the hue
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: That I would choose, were I to choose anew.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Clear up, fair queen, that cloudy countenance:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Though chance of war hath wrought this change of cheer,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Thou comest not to be made a scorn in Rome:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Princely shall be thy usage every way.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Rest on my word, and let not discontent
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Daunt all your hopes: madam, he comforts you
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Can make you greater than the Queen of Goths.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Lavinia, you are not displeased with this?
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Not I, my lord; sith true nobility
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Warrants these words in princely courtesy.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Thanks, sweet Lavinia. Romans, let us go;
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Ransomless here we set our prisoners free:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Proclaim our honours, lords, with trump and drum.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Flourish. SATURNINUS courts TAMORA in dumb show
BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Lord Titus, by your leave, this maid is mine.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Seizing LAVINIA
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: How, sir! are you in earnest then, my lord?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Ay, noble Titus; and resolved withal
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: [Coming forward]  Why, how now, lords!
speaker: AARON

string: So near the emperor's palace dare you draw,
speaker: AARON

string: And maintain such a quarrel openly?
speaker: AARON

string: Full well I wot the ground of all this grudge:
speaker: AARON

string: I would not for a million of gold
speaker: AARON

string: The cause were known to them it most concerns;
speaker: AARON

string: Nor would your noble mother for much more
speaker: AARON

string: Be so dishonour'd in the court of Rome.
speaker: AARON

string: For shame, put up.
speaker: AARON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Not I, till I have sheathed
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: My rapier in his bosom and withal
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Thrust these reproachful speeches down his throat
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: That he hath breathed in my dishonour here.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: For that I am prepared and full resolved.
speaker: CHIRON

string: Foul-spoken coward, that thunder'st with thy tongue,
speaker: CHIRON

string: And with thy weapon nothing darest perform!
speaker: CHIRON

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Away, I say!
speaker: AARON

string: Now, by the gods that warlike Goths adore,
speaker: AARON

string: This petty brabble will undo us all.
speaker: AARON

string: Why, lords, and think you not how dangerous
speaker: AARON

string: It is to jet upon a prince's right?
speaker: AARON

string: What, is Lavinia then become so loose,
speaker: AARON

string: Or Bassianus so degenerate,
speaker: AARON

string: That for her love such quarrels may be broach'd
speaker: AARON

string: Without controlment, justice, or revenge?
speaker: AARON

string: Young lords, beware! and should the empress know
speaker: AARON

string: This discord's ground, the music would not please.
speaker: AARON

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: I care not, I, knew she and all the world:
speaker: CHIRON

string: I love Lavinia more than all the world.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Youngling, learn thou to make some meaner choice:
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Lavinia is thine elder brother's hope.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Why, are ye mad? or know ye not, in Rome
speaker: AARON

string: How furious and impatient they be,
speaker: AARON

string: And cannot brook competitors in love?
speaker: AARON

string: I tell you, lords, you do but plot your deaths
speaker: AARON

string: By this device.
speaker: AARON

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Aaron, a thousand deaths
speaker: CHIRON

string: Would I propose to achieve her whom I love.
speaker: CHIRON

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: To achieve her! how?
speaker: AARON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Why makest thou it so strange?
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: She is a woman, therefore may be woo'd;
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: She is a woman, therefore may be won;
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: She is Lavinia, therefore must be loved.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: What, man! more water glideth by the mill
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Than wots the miller of; and easy it is
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Of a cut loaf to steal a shive, we know:
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Though Bassianus be the emperor's brother.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Better than he have worn Vulcan's badge.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: [Aside]  Ay, and as good as Saturninus may.
speaker: AARON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Then why should he despair that knows to court it
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: With words, fair looks and liberality?
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: What, hast not thou full often struck a doe,
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: And borne her cleanly by the keeper's nose?
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Why, then, it seems, some certain snatch or so
speaker: AARON

string: Would serve your turns.
speaker: AARON

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Ay, so the turn were served.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Aaron, thou hast hit it.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Would you had hit it too!
speaker: AARON

string: Then should not we be tired with this ado.
speaker: AARON

string: Why, hark ye, hark ye! and are you such fools
speaker: AARON

string: To square for this? would it offend you, then
speaker: AARON

string: That both should speed?
speaker: AARON

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Faith, not me.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Nor me, so I were one.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: For shame, be friends, and join for that you jar:
speaker: AARON

string: 'Tis policy and stratagem must do
speaker: AARON

string: That you affect; and so must you resolve,
speaker: AARON

string: That what you cannot as you would achieve,
speaker: AARON

string: You must perforce accomplish as you may.
speaker: AARON

string: Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste
speaker: AARON

string: Than this Lavinia, Bassianus' love.
speaker: AARON

string: A speedier course than lingering languishment
speaker: AARON

string: Must we pursue, and I have found the path.
speaker: AARON

string: My lords, a solemn hunting is in hand;
speaker: AARON

string: There will the lovely Roman ladies troop:
speaker: AARON

string: The forest walks are wide and spacious;
speaker: AARON

string: And many unfrequented plots there are
speaker: AARON

string: Fitted by kind for rape and villany:
speaker: AARON

string: Single you thither then this dainty doe,
speaker: AARON

string: And strike her home by force, if not by words:
speaker: AARON

string: This way, or not at all, stand you in hope.
speaker: AARON

string: Come, come, our empress, with her sacred wit
speaker: AARON

string: To villany and vengeance consecrate,
speaker: AARON

string: Will we acquaint with all that we intend;
speaker: AARON

string: And she shall file our engines with advice,
speaker: AARON

string: That will not suffer you to square yourselves,
speaker: AARON

string: But to your wishes' height advance you both.
speaker: AARON

string: The emperor's court is like the house of Fame,
speaker: AARON

string: The palace full of tongues, of eyes, and ears:
speaker: AARON

string: The woods are ruthless, dreadful, deaf, and dull;
speaker: AARON

string: There speak, and strike, brave boys, and take
speaker: AARON

string: your turns;
speaker: AARON

string: There serve your lusts, shadow'd from heaven's eye,
speaker: AARON

string: And revel in Lavinia's treasury.
speaker: AARON

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Thy counsel, lad, smells of no cowardice,
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Sit fas aut nefas, till I find the stream
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: To cool this heat, a charm to calm these fits.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Per Styga, per manes vehor.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Exeunt
SCENE II. A forest near Rome. Horns and cry of hounds heard.
Enter TITUS ANDRONICUS, with Hunters,  & c., MARCUS, LUCIUS, QUINTUS, and MARTIUS
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The hunt is up, the morn is bright and grey,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The fields are fragrant and the woods are green:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Uncouple here and let us make a bay
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And wake the emperor and his lovely bride
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And rouse the prince and ring a hunter's peal,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That all the court may echo with the noise.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Sons, let it be your charge, as it is ours,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To attend the emperor's person carefully:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I have been troubled in my sleep this night,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But dawning day new comfort hath inspired.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: A cry of hounds and horns, winded in a peal. Enter  SATURNINUS, TAMORA, BASSIANUS, LAVINIA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, and Attendants
Many good morrows to your majesty;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Madam, to you as many and as good:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I promised your grace a hunter's peal.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And you have rung it lustily, my lord;
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Somewhat too early for new-married ladies.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Lavinia, how say you?
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: I say, no;
speaker: LAVINIA

string: I have been broad awake two hours and more.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Come on, then; horse and chariots let us have,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And to our sport.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: To TAMORA
Madam, now shall ye see
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Our Roman hunting.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: I have dogs, my lord,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Will rouse the proudest panther in the chase,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And climb the highest promontory top.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And I have horse will follow where the game
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Makes way, and run like swallows o'er the plain.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Chiron, we hunt not, we, with horse nor hound,
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: But hope to pluck a dainty doe to ground.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Exeunt
SCENE III. A lonely part of the forest.
Enter AARON, with a bag of gold
AARON
speaker: AARON

string: He that had wit would think that I had none,
speaker: AARON

string: To bury so much gold under a tree,
speaker: AARON

string: And never after to inherit it.
speaker: AARON

string: Let him that thinks of me so abjectly
speaker: AARON

string: Know that this gold must coin a stratagem,
speaker: AARON

string: Which, cunningly effected, will beget
speaker: AARON

string: A very excellent piece of villany:
speaker: AARON

string: And so repose, sweet gold, for their unrest
speaker: AARON

string: Hides the gold
That have their alms out of the empress' chest.
speaker: AARON

string: Enter TAMORA
TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad,
speaker: TAMORA

string: When every thing doth make a gleeful boast?
speaker: TAMORA

string: The birds chant melody on every bush,
speaker: TAMORA

string: The snake lies rolled in the cheerful sun,
speaker: TAMORA

string: The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind
speaker: TAMORA

string: And make a chequer'd shadow on the ground:
speaker: TAMORA

string: Under their sweet shade, Aaron, let us sit,
speaker: TAMORA

string: And, whilst the babbling echo mocks the hounds,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Replying shrilly to the well-tuned horns,
speaker: TAMORA

string: As if a double hunt were heard at once,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Let us sit down and mark their yelping noise;
speaker: TAMORA

string: And, after conflict such as was supposed
speaker: TAMORA

string: The wandering prince and Dido once enjoy'd,
speaker: TAMORA

string: When with a happy storm they were surprised
speaker: TAMORA

string: And curtain'd with a counsel-keeping cave,
speaker: TAMORA

string: We may, each wreathed in the other's arms,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Our pastimes done, possess a golden slumber;
speaker: TAMORA

string: Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds
speaker: TAMORA

string: Be unto us as is a nurse's song
speaker: TAMORA

string: Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.
speaker: TAMORA

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Madam, though Venus govern your desires,
speaker: AARON

string: Saturn is dominator over mine:
speaker: AARON

string: What signifies my deadly-standing eye,
speaker: AARON

string: My silence and my cloudy melancholy,
speaker: AARON

string: My fleece of woolly hair that now uncurls
speaker: AARON

string: Even as an adder when she doth unroll
speaker: AARON

string: To do some fatal execution?
speaker: AARON

string: No, madam, these are no venereal signs:
speaker: AARON

string: Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,
speaker: AARON

string: Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.
speaker: AARON

string: Hark Tamora, the empress of my soul,
speaker: AARON

string: Which never hopes more heaven than rests in thee,
speaker: AARON

string: This is the day of doom for Bassianus:
speaker: AARON

string: His Philomel must lose her tongue to-day,
speaker: AARON

string: Thy sons make pillage of her chastity
speaker: AARON

string: And wash their hands in Bassianus' blood.
speaker: AARON

string: Seest thou this letter? take it up, I pray thee,
speaker: AARON

string: And give the king this fatal plotted scroll.
speaker: AARON

string: Now question me no more; we are espied;
speaker: AARON

string: Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty,
speaker: AARON

string: Which dreads not yet their lives' destruction.
speaker: AARON

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Ah, my sweet Moor, sweeter to me than life!
speaker: TAMORA

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: No more, great empress; Bassianus comes:
speaker: AARON

string: Be cross with him; and I'll go fetch thy sons
speaker: AARON

string: To back thy quarrels, whatsoe'er they be.
speaker: AARON

string: Exit
Enter BASSIANUS and LAVINIA
BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Who have we here? Rome's royal empress,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Unfurnish'd of her well-beseeming troop?

string: Or is it Dian, habited like her,
speaker: BASSIANUS

speaker: BASSIANUS

string: To see the general hunting in this forest?
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Saucy controller of our private steps!
speaker: TAMORA

string: Had I the power that some say Dian had,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Thy temples should be planted presently
speaker: TAMORA

string: With horns, as was Actaeon's; and the hounds
speaker: TAMORA

string: Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Unmannerly intruder as thou art!
speaker: TAMORA

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Under your patience, gentle empress,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: 'Tis thought you have a goodly gift in horning;
speaker: LAVINIA

string: And to be doubted that your Moor and you
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Are singled forth to try experiments:
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Jove shield your husband from his hounds to-day!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: 'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Believe me, queen, your swarth Cimmerian
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Doth make your honour of his body's hue,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Spotted, detested, and abominable.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Why are you sequester'd from all your train,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Dismounted from your snow-white goodly steed.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: And wander'd hither to an obscure plot,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: Accompanied but with a barbarous Moor,
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: If foul desire had not conducted you?
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: And, being intercepted in your sport,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Great reason that my noble lord be rated
speaker: LAVINIA

string: For sauciness. I pray you, let us hence,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: And let her joy her raven-colour'd love;
speaker: LAVINIA

string: This valley fits the purpose passing well.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: BASSIANUS
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: The king my brother shall have note of this.
speaker: BASSIANUS

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Ay, for these slips have made him noted long:
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Good king, to be so mightily abused!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Why have I patience to endure all this?
speaker: TAMORA

string: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON
DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: How now, dear sovereign, and our gracious mother!
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Why doth your highness look so pale and wan?
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Have I not reason, think you, to look pale?
speaker: TAMORA

string: These two have 'ticed me hither to this place:
speaker: TAMORA

string: A barren detested vale, you see it is;
speaker: TAMORA

string: The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean,
speaker: TAMORA

string: O'ercome with moss and baleful mistletoe:
speaker: TAMORA

string: Here never shines the sun; here nothing breeds,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven:
speaker: TAMORA

string: And when they show'd me this abhorred pit,
speaker: TAMORA

string: They told me, here, at dead time of the night,
speaker: TAMORA

string: A thousand fiends, a thousand hissing snakes,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Ten thousand swelling toads, as many urchins,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Would make such fearful and confused cries
speaker: TAMORA

string: As any mortal body hearing it
speaker: TAMORA

string: Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.
speaker: TAMORA

string: No sooner had they told this hellish tale,
speaker: TAMORA

string: But straight they told me they would bind me here
speaker: TAMORA

string: Unto the body of a dismal yew,
speaker: TAMORA

string: And leave me to this miserable death:
speaker: TAMORA

string: And then they call'd me foul adulteress,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms
speaker: TAMORA

string: That ever ear did hear to such effect:
speaker: TAMORA

string: And, had you not by wondrous fortune come,
speaker: TAMORA

string: This vengeance on me had they executed.
speaker: TAMORA

string: Revenge it, as you love your mother's life,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Or be ye not henceforth call'd my children.
speaker: TAMORA

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: This is a witness that I am thy son.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Stabs BASSIANUS
CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: And this for me, struck home to show my strength.

string: Also stabs BASSIANUS, who dies
LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Ay, come, Semiramis, nay, barbarous Tamora,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: For no name fits thy nature but thy own!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Give me thy poniard; you shall know, my boys
speaker: TAMORA

string: Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.
speaker: TAMORA

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Stay, madam; here is more belongs to her;
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw:
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: This minion stood upon her chastity,
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty,
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: And with that painted hope braves your mightiness:
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: And shall she carry this unto her grave?
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: An if she do, I would I were an eunuch.
speaker: CHIRON

string: Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,
speaker: CHIRON

string: And make his dead trunk pillow to our lust.
speaker: CHIRON

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: But when ye have the honey ye desire,

speaker: TAMORA

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: I warrant you, madam, we wil l make that sure.
speaker: CHIRON

string: Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy
speaker: CHIRON

string: That nice-preserved honesty of yours.
speaker: CHIRON

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: O Tamora! thou bear'st a woman's face,--
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: I will not hear her speak; away with her!
speaker: TAMORA

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

speaker: LAVINIA

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Listen, fair madam: let it be your glory

string: As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:
speaker: LAVINIA

string: To CHIRON
Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?
speaker: CHIRON

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: 'Tis true; the raven doth not hatch a lark:
speaker: LAVINIA

speaker: LAVINIA

speaker: LAVINIA

string: O, be to me, though thy hard heart say no,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Nothing so kind, but something pitiful!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: I know not what it means; away with her!
speaker: TAMORA

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: O, let me teach thee! for my father's sake,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: That gave thee life, when well he might have
speaker: LAVINIA

string: slain thee,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Be not obdurate, open thy deaf ears.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me,
speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA
