speaker: LAVINIA

string: Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: What begg'st thou, then? fond woman, let me go.
speaker: TAMORA

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: 'Tis present death I beg; and one thing more
speaker: LAVINIA

string: That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:
speaker: LAVINIA

string: O, keep me from their worse than killing lust,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: And tumble me into some loathsome pit,
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Where never man's eye may behold my body:
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Do this, and be a charitable murderer.
speaker: LAVINIA

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee:
speaker: TAMORA

string: No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.
speaker: TAMORA

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: LAVINIA
speaker: LAVINIA

string: No grace? no womanhood? Ah, beastly creature!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: The blot and enemy to our general name!
speaker: LAVINIA

string: Confusion fall--
speaker: LAVINIA

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Nay, then I'll stop your mouth. Bring thou her husband:
speaker: CHIRON

string: This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS throws the body of BASSIANUS into the  pit; then exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, dragging off LAVINIA
TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Farewell, my sons: see that you make her sure.
speaker: TAMORA

string: Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed,
speaker: TAMORA

string: Till all the Andronici be made away.
speaker: TAMORA

string: Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor,
speaker: TAMORA

string: And let my spleenful sons this trull deflow'r.
speaker: TAMORA

string: Exit
Re-enter AARON, with QUINTUS and MARTIUS
AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Come on, my lords, the better foot before:
speaker: AARON

string: Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit
speaker: AARON

string: Where I espied the panther fast asleep.
speaker: AARON

string: QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: My sight is very dull, whate'er it bodes.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: And mine, I promise you; were't not for shame,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Well could I leave our sport to sleep awhile.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Falls into the pit
QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: What art thou fall'n? What subtle hole is this,
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Whose mouth is cover'd with rude-growing briers,
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed blood
speaker: QUINTUS

string: As fresh as morning dew distill'd on flowers?
speaker: QUINTUS

string: A very fatal place it seems to me.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Speak, brother, hast thou hurt thee with the fall?
speaker: QUINTUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: O brother, with the dismall'st object hurt
speaker: MARTIUS

string: That ever eye with sight made heart lament!
speaker: MARTIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: [Aside]  Now will I fetch the king to find them here,
speaker: AARON

string: That he thereby may give a likely guess
speaker: AARON

string: How these were they that made away his brother.
speaker: AARON

string: Exit
MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Why dost not comfort me, and help me out
speaker: MARTIUS

string: From this unhallowed and blood-stained hole?
speaker: MARTIUS

string: QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: I am surprised with an uncouth fear;
speaker: QUINTUS

string: A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints:
speaker: QUINTUS

string: My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: To prove thou hast a true-divining heart,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Aaron and thou look down into this den,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: And see a fearful sight of blood and death.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Aaron is gone; and my compassionate heart
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Will not permit mine eyes once to behold
speaker: QUINTUS

string: The thing whereat it trembles by surmise;
speaker: QUINTUS

string: O, tell me how it is; for ne'er till now
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Was I a child to fear I know not what.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Lord Bassianus lies embrewed here,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: All on a heap, like to a slaughter'd lamb,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: If it be dark, how dost thou know 'tis he?
speaker: QUINTUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Upon his bloody finger he doth wear
speaker: MARTIUS

string: A precious ring, that lightens all the hole,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Which, like a taper in some monument,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Doth shine upon the dead man's earthy cheeks,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: And shows the ragged entrails of the pit:
speaker: MARTIUS

string: So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus
speaker: MARTIUS

string: When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: O brother, help me with thy fainting hand--
speaker: MARTIUS

string: If fear hath made thee faint, as me it hath--
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Out of this fell devouring receptacle,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: As hateful as Cocytus' misty mouth.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Reach me thy hand, that I may help thee out;
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Or, wanting strength to do thee so much good,
speaker: QUINTUS

string: I may be pluck'd into the swallowing womb
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus' grave.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Nor I no strength to climb without thy help.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: QUINTUS
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Thy hand once more; I will not loose again,
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Till thou art here aloft, or I below:
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Thou canst not come to me: I come to thee.
speaker: QUINTUS

string: Falls in
Enter SATURNINUS with AARON
SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Along with me: I'll see what hole is here,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: And what he is that now is leap'd into it.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Say who art thou that lately didst descend
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Into this gaping hollow of the earth?
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: The unhappy son of old Andronicus:
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,
speaker: MARTIUS

string: To find thy brother Bassianus dead.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: He and his lady both are at the lodge
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Upon the north side of this pleasant chase;
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: 'Tis not an hour since I left him there.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: MARTIUS
speaker: MARTIUS

string: We know not where you left him all alive;
speaker: MARTIUS

string: But, out, alas! here have we found him dead.
speaker: MARTIUS

string: Re-enter TAMORA, with Attendants; TITUS ANDRONICUS, and Lucius
TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Where is my lord the king?
speaker: TAMORA

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Here, Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Where is thy brother Bassianus?
speaker: TAMORA

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Then all too late I bring this fatal writ,
speaker: TAMORA

string: The complot of this timeless tragedy;
speaker: TAMORA

string: And wonder greatly that man's face can fold
speaker: TAMORA

string: In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.
speaker: TAMORA

string: She giveth SATURNINUS a letter
SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: [Reads]  'An if we miss to meet him handsomely--
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Sweet huntsman, Bassianus 'tis we mean--
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Do thou so much as dig the grave for him:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Thou know'st our meaning. Look for thy reward
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Among the nettles at the elder-tree
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Which overshades the mouth of that same pit
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Do this, and purchase us thy lasting friends.'
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: O Tamora! was ever heard the like?
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: This is the pit, and this the elder-tree.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: That should have murdered Bassianus here.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.
speaker: AARON

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: [To TITUS]  Two of thy whelps, fell curs of
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: bloody kind,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Have here bereft my brother of his life.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: There let them bide until we have devised
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: What, are they in this pit? O wondrous thing!
speaker: TAMORA

string: How easily murder is discovered!
speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: High emperor, upon my feeble knee
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I beg this boon, with tears not lightly shed,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That this fell fault of my accursed sons,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Accursed if the fault be proved in them,--
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: If it be proved! you see it is apparent.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Andronicus himself did take it up.
speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I did, my lord: yet let me be their bail;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For, by my father's reverend tomb, I vow
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: They shall be ready at your highness' will
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To answer their suspicion with their lives.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Thou shalt not bail them: see thou follow me.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Some bring the murder'd body, some the murderers:
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: Let them not speak a word; the guilt is plain;
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: For, by my soul, were there worse end than death,
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: That end upon them should be executed.
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Andronicus, I will entreat the king;
speaker: TAMORA

string: Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.
speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Come, Lucius, come; stay not to talk with them.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON with LAVINIA, ravished; her hands cut off, and her tongue cut out
DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: So, now go tell, an if thy tongue can speak,
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Who 'twas that cut thy tongue and ravish'd thee.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Write down thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,
speaker: CHIRON

string: An if thy stumps will let thee play the scribe.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: See, how with signs and tokens she can scrowl.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Go home, call for sweet water, wash thy hands.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash;
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: And so let's leave her to her silent walks.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: An 'twere my case, I should go hang myself.
speaker: CHIRON

string: DEMETRIUS
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.
speaker: DEMETRIUS

string: Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON
Enter MARCUS
MARCUS
speaker: MARCUS

string: Who is this? my niece, that flies away so fast!
speaker: MARCUS

string: Cousin, a word; where is your husband?
speaker: MARCUS

string: If I do dream, would all my wealth would wake me!
speaker: MARCUS

string: If I do wake, some planet strike me down,
speaker: MARCUS

string: That I may slumber in eternal sleep!
speaker: MARCUS

string: Speak, gentle niece, what stern ungentle hands
speaker: MARCUS

string: Have lopp'd and hew'd and made thy body bare
speaker: MARCUS

string: Of her two branches, those sweet ornaments,
speaker: MARCUS

string: Whose circling shadows kings have sought to sleep in,
speaker: MARCUS

string: And might not gain so great a happiness
speaker: MARCUS

string: As have thy love? Why dost not speak to me?
speaker: MARCUS

string: Alas, a crimson river of warm blood,
speaker: MARCUS

string: Like to a bubbling fountain stirr'd with wind,
speaker: MARCUS

string: Doth rise and fall between thy rosed lips,
speaker: MARCUS

string: Coming and going with thy honey breath.
speaker: MARCUS

string: But, sure, some Tereus hath deflowered thee,
speaker: MARCUS

string: And, lest thou shouldst detect him, cut thy tongue.
speaker: MARCUS

string: Ah, now thou turn'st away thy face for shame!
speaker: MARCUS

string: And, notwithstanding all this loss of blood,
speaker: MARCUS

string: As from a conduit with three issuing spouts,
speaker: MARCUS

string: Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titan's face
speaker: MARCUS

string: Blushing to be encountered with a cloud.
speaker: MARCUS

string: Shall I speak for thee? shall I say 'tis so?
speaker: MARCUS

string: O, that I knew thy heart; and knew the beast,
speaker: MARCUS

string: That I might rail at him, to ease my mind!
speaker: MARCUS

string: Sorrow concealed, like an oven stopp'd,
speaker: MARCUS

string: Doth burn the heart to cinders where it is.
speaker: MARCUS

string: Fair Philomela, she but lost her tongue,
speaker: MARCUS

string: And in a tedious sampler sew'd her mind:
speaker: MARCUS

string: But, lovely niece, that mean is cut from thee;
speaker: MARCUS

string: A craftier Tereus, cousin, hast thou met,
speaker: MARCUS

string: And he hath cut those pretty fingers off,
speaker: MARCUS

string: That could have better sew'd than Philomel.
speaker: MARCUS

string: O, had the monster seen those lily hands
speaker: MARCUS

string: Tremble, like aspen-leaves, upon a lute,
speaker: MARCUS

string: And make the silken strings delight to kiss them,
speaker: MARCUS

string: He would not then have touch'd them for his life!
speaker: MARCUS

string: Or, had he heard the heavenly harmony
speaker: MARCUS

string: Which that sweet tongue hath made,
speaker: MARCUS

string: He would have dropp'd his knife, and fell asleep
speaker: MARCUS

string: As Cerberus at the Thracian poet's feet.
speaker: MARCUS

string: Come, let us go, and make thy father blind;
speaker: MARCUS

string: For such a sight will blind a father's eye:
speaker: MARCUS

string: One hour's storm will drown the fragrant meads;
speaker: MARCUS

string: What will whole months of tears thy father's eyes?
speaker: MARCUS

string: Do not draw back, for we will mourn with thee
speaker: MARCUS

string: O, could our mourning ease thy misery!
speaker: MARCUS

string: Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. Rome. A street.
Enter Judges, Senators and Tribunes, with MARTIUS  and QUINTUS, bound, passing on to the place of execution; TITUS going before, pleading
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hear me, grave fathers! noble tribunes, stay!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For pity of mine age, whose youth was spent
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In dangerous wars, whilst you securely slept;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For all the frosty nights that I have watch'd;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And for these bitter tears, which now you see
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Be pitiful to my condemned sons,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Whose souls are not corrupted as 'tis thought.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For two and twenty sons I never wept,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Because they died in honour's lofty bed.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lieth down; the Judges,  & c., pass by him, and Exeunt
For these, these, tribunes, in the dust I write
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Let my tears stanch the earth's dry appetite;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: My sons' sweet blood will make it shame and blush.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O earth, I will befriend thee more with rain,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That shall distil from these two ancient urns,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Than youthful April shall with all his showers:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In summer's drought I'll drop upon thee still;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In winter with warm tears I'll melt the snow
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And keep eternal spring-time on thy face,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: So thou refuse to drink my dear sons' blood.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Enter LUCIUS, with his sword drawn
O reverend tribunes! O gentle, aged men!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Unbind my sons, reverse the doom of death;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And let me say, that never wept before,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: My tears are now prevailing orators.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: O noble father, you lament in vain:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: The tribunes hear you not; no man is by;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And you recount your sorrows to a stone.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ah, Lucius, for thy brothers let me plead.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Grave tribunes, once more I entreat of you,--
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: My gracious lord, no tribune hears you speak.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why, tis no matter, man; if they did hear,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: They would not mark me, or if they did mark,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: They would not pity me, yet plead I must;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Therefore I tell my sorrows to the stones;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Who, though they cannot answer my distress,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Yet in some sort they are better than the tribunes,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For that they will not intercept my tale:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: When I do weep, they humbly at my feet
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Receive my tears and seem to weep with me;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And, were they but attired in grave weeds,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Rome could afford no tribune like to these.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: A stone is soft as wax,--tribunes more hard than stones;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: A stone is silent, and offendeth not,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And tribunes with their tongues doom men to death.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Rises
But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: To rescue my two brothers from their death:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: For which attempt the judges have pronounced
speaker: LUCIUS

string: My everlasting doom of banishment.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O happy man! they have befriended thee.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why, foolish Lucius, dost thou not perceive
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That Rome is but a wilderness of tigers?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tigers must prey, and Rome affords no prey
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But me and mine: how happy art thou, then,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: From these devourers to be banished!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But who comes with our brother Marcus here?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Enter MARCUS and LAVINIA
MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Titus, prepare thy aged eyes to weep;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or, if not so, thy noble heart to break:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Will it consume me? let me see it, then.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: This was thy daughter.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why, Marcus, so she is.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Ay me, this object kills me!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Faint-hearted boy, arise, and look upon her.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Speak, Lavinia, what accursed hand
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: What fool hath added water to the sea,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or brought a faggot to bright-burning Troy?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: My grief was at the height before thou camest,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And now like Nilus, it disdaineth bounds.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Give me a sword, I'll chop off my hands too;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For they have fought for Rome, and all in vain;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And they have nursed this woe, in feeding life;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In bootless prayer have they been held up,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And they have served me to effectless use:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now all the service I require of them
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Is that the one will help to cut the other.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: 'Tis well, Lavinia, that thou hast no hands;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For hands, to do Rome service, are but vain.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Speak, gentle sister, who hath martyr'd thee?
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: O, that delightful engine of her thoughts
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That blabb'd them with such pleasing eloquence,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Where, like a sweet melodious bird, it sung
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Sweet varied notes, enchanting every ear!
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: O, say thou for her, who hath done this deed?
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: O, thus I found her, straying in the park,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Seeking to hide herself, as doth the deer
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That hath received some unrecuring wound.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: It was my deer; and he that wounded her
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hath hurt me more than had he killed me dead:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For now I stand as one upon a rock
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Environed with a wilderness of sea,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Who marks the waxing tide grow wave by wave,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Expecting ever when some envious surge
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: This way to death my wretched sons are gone;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Here stands my other son, a banished man,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And here my brother, weeping at my woes.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Is dear Lavinia, dearer than my soul.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Had I but seen thy picture in this plight,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: It would have madded me: what shall I do
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now I behold thy lively body so?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou hast no hands, to wipe away thy tears:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Nor tongue, to tell me who hath martyr'd thee:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy husband he is dead: and for his death
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy brothers are condemn'd, and dead by this.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Look, Marcus! ah, son Lucius, look on her!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: When I did name her brothers, then fresh tears
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Stood on her cheeks, as doth the honey-dew
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Upon a gather'd lily almost wither'd.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Perchance she weeps because they kill'd her husband;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Perchance because she knows them innocent.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: If they did kill thy husband, then be joyful
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: No, no, they would not do so foul a deed;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Gentle Lavinia, let me kiss thy lips.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or make some sign how I may do thee ease:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Shall thy good uncle, and thy brother Lucius,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And thou, and I, sit round about some fountain,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Looking all downwards to behold our cheeks
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: How they are stain'd, as meadows, yet not dry,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: With miry slime left on them by a flood?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And in the fountain shall we gaze so long
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And made a brine-pit with our bitter tears?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or shall we cut away our hands, like thine?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or shall we bite our tongues, and in dumb shows
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Pass the remainder of our hateful days?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: What shall we do? let us, that have our tongues,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Plot some deuce of further misery,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To make us wonder'd at in time to come.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Sweet father, cease your tears; for, at your grief,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Patience, dear niece. Good Titus, dry thine eyes.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ah, Marcus, Marcus! brother, well I wot
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For thou, poor man, hast drown'd it with thine own.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Ah, my Lavinia, I will wipe thy cheeks.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Mark, Marcus, mark! I understand her signs:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Had she a tongue to speak, now would she say
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That to her brother which I said to thee:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: His napkin, with his true tears all bewet,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Can do no service on her sorrowful cheeks.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O, what a sympathy of woe is this,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As far from help as Limbo is from bliss!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Enter AARON
AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Titus Andronicus, my lord the emperor
speaker: AARON

string: Sends thee this word,--that, if thou love thy sons,
speaker: AARON

string: Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus,
speaker: AARON

string: Or any one of you, chop off your hand,
speaker: AARON

string: And send it to the king: he for the same
speaker: AARON

string: Will send thee hither both thy sons alive;
speaker: AARON

string: And that shall be the ransom for their fault.
speaker: AARON

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O gracious emperor! O gentle Aaron!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Did ever raven sing so like a lark,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That gives sweet tidings of the sun's uprise?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: With all my heart, I'll send the emperor My hand:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Good Aaron, wilt thou help to chop it off?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Stay, father! for that noble hand of thine,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That hath thrown down so many enemies,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Shall not be sent: my hand will serve the turn:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: My youth can better spare my blood than you;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And rear'd aloft the bloody battle-axe,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Writing destruction on the enemy's castle?
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: O, none of both but are of high desert:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: My hand hath been but idle; let it serve
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: To ransom my two nephews from their death;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then have I kept it to a worthy end.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: Nay, come, agree whose hand shall go along,
speaker: AARON

string: For fear they die before their pardon come.
speaker: AARON

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: My hand shall go.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: By heaven, it shall not go!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Sirs, strive no more: such wither'd herbs as these
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Are meet for plucking up, and therefore mine.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Sweet father, if I shall be thought thy son,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Let me redeem my brothers both from death.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And, for our father's sake and mother's care,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now let me show a brother's love to thee.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Agree between you; I will spare my hand.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Then I'll go fetch an axe.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: But I will use the axe.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Exeunt LUCIUS and MARCUS
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Come hither, Aaron; I'll deceive them both:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lend me thy hand, and I will give thee mine.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: [Aside]  If that be call'd deceit, I will be honest,
speaker: AARON

string: And never, whilst I live, deceive men so:
speaker: AARON

string: But I'll deceive you in another sort,
speaker: AARON

string: And that you'll say, ere half an hour pass.
speaker: AARON

string: Cuts off TITUS's hand
Re-enter LUCIUS and MARCUS
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now stay your strife: what shall be is dispatch'd.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Good Aaron, give his majesty my hand:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tell him it was a hand that warded him
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: From thousand dangers; bid him bury it
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: More hath it merited; that let it have.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As for my sons, say I account of them
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As jewels purchased at an easy price;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And yet dear too, because I bought mine own.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: I go, Andronicus: and for thy hand
speaker: AARON

string: Look by and by to have thy sons with thee.
speaker: AARON

string: Aside
Their heads, I mean. O, how this villany
speaker: AARON

string: Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it!
speaker: AARON

string: Let fools do good, and fair men call for grace.
speaker: AARON

string: Aaron will have his soul black like his face.
speaker: AARON

string: Exit
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O, here I lift this one hand up to heaven,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And bow this feeble ruin to the earth:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: If any power pities wretched tears,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To that I call!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To LAVINIA
What, wilt thou kneel with me?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Do, then, dear heart; for heaven shall hear our prayers;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or with our sighs we'll breathe the welkin dim,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And stain the sun with fog, as sometime clouds
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: O brother, speak with possibilities,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And do not break into these deep extremes.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Is not my sorrow deep, having no bottom?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then be my passions bottomless with them.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: But yet let reason govern thy lament.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: If there were reason for these miseries,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then into limits could I bind my woes:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: When heaven doth weep, doth not the earth o'erflow?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: If the winds rage, doth not the sea wax mad,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Threatening the welkin with his big-swoln face?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I am the sea; hark, how her sighs do blow!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: She is the weeping welkin, I the earth:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then must my sea be moved with her sighs;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then must my earth with her continual tears
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Become a deluge, overflow'd and drown'd;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For why my bowels cannot hide her woes,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But like a drunkard must I vomit them.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then give me leave, for losers will have leave
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Enter a Messenger, with two heads and a hand
Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid
speaker: Messenger

string: For that good hand thou sent'st the emperor.
speaker: Messenger

string: Here are the heads of thy two noble sons;
speaker: Messenger

string: And here's thy hand, in scorn to thee sent back;
speaker: Messenger

string: Thy griefs their sports, thy resolution mock'd;
speaker: Messenger

string: That woe is me to think upon thy woes
speaker: Messenger

string: More than remembrance of my father's death.
speaker: Messenger

string: Exit
MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now let hot AEtna cool in Sicily,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And be my heart an ever-burning hell!
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: These miseries are more than may be borne.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: To weep with them that weep doth ease some deal;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: But sorrow flouted at is double death.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Ah, that this sight should make so deep a wound,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And yet detested life not shrink thereat!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That ever death should let life bear his name,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Where life hath no more interest but to breathe!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: LAVINIA kisses TITUS
MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Alas, poor heart, that kiss is comfortless
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: As frozen water to a starved snake.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: When will this fearful slumber have an end?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now, farewell, flattery: die, Andronicus;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou dost not slumber: see, thy two sons' heads,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy warlike hand, thy mangled daughter here:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy other banish'd son, with this dear sight
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Struck pale and bloodless; and thy brother, I,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Even like a stony image, cold and numb.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ah, now no more will I control thy griefs:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Rend off thy silver hair, thy other hand
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Gnawing with thy teeth; and be this dismal sight
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: The closing up of our most wretched eyes;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Now is a time to storm; why art thou still?
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ha, ha, ha!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this hour.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why, I have not another tear to shed:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Besides, this sorrow is an enemy,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And would usurp upon my watery eyes
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And make them blind with tributary tears:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then which way shall I find Revenge's cave?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For these two heads do seem to speak to me,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And threat me I shall never come to bliss
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Till all these mischiefs be return'd again
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Even in their throats that have committed them.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Come, let me see what task I have to do.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: You heavy people, circle me about,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That I may turn me to each one of you,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And swear unto my soul to right your wrongs.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The vow is made. Come, brother, take a head;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And in this hand the other I will bear.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lavinia, thou shalt be employ'd: these arms!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Bear thou my hand, sweet wench, between thy teeth.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As for thee, boy, go get thee from my sight;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou art an exile, and thou must not stay:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hie to the Goths, and raise an army there:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And, if you love me, as I think you do,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Let's kiss and part, for we have much to do.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Exeunt TITUS, MARCUS, and LAVINIA
LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Farewell Andronicus, my noble father,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: The wofull'st man that ever lived in Rome:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Farewell, proud Rome; till Lucius come again,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: He leaves his pledges dearer than his life:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Farewell, Lavinia, my noble sister;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: O, would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives
speaker: LUCIUS

string: But in oblivion and hateful griefs.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: If Lucius live, he will requite your wrongs;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And make proud Saturnine and his empress
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Beg at the gates, like Tarquin and his queen.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Now will I to the Goths, and raise a power,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: To be revenged on Rome and Saturnine.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Exit
SCENE II. A room in Titus's house. A banquet set out.
Enter TITUS, MARCUS, LAVINIA and Young LUCIUS, a boy
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: So, so; now sit: and look you eat no more
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Than will preserve just so much strength in us
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Marcus, unknit that sorrow-wreathen knot:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy niece and I, poor creatures, want our hands,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And cannot passionate our tenfold grief
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: With folded arms. This poor right hand of mine
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Is left to tyrannize upon my breast;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Who, when my heart, all mad with misery,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Beats in this hollow prison of my flesh,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Then thus I thump it down.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To LAVINIA
Thou map of woe, that thus dost talk in signs!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: When thy poor heart beats with outrageous beating,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou canst not strike it thus to make it still.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Wound it with sighing, girl, kill it with groans;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or get some little knife between thy teeth,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And just against thy heart make thou a hole;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: That all the tears that thy poor eyes let fall
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: May run into that sink, and soaking in
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Drown the lamenting fool in sea-salt tears.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Fie, brother, fie! teach her not thus to lay
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Such violent hands upon her tender life.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: How now! has sorrow made thee dote already?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Why, Marcus, no man should be mad but I.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: What violent hands can she lay on her life?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Ah, wherefore dost thou urge the name of hands;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To bid AEneas tell the tale twice o'er,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: How Troy was burnt and he made miserable?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O, handle not the theme, to talk of hands,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lest we remember still that we have none.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Fie, fie, how franticly I square my talk,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As if we should forget we had no hands,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: If Marcus did not name the word of hands!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Come, let's fall to; and, gentle girl, eat this:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Here is no drink! Hark, Marcus, what she says;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I can interpret all her martyr'd signs;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: She says she drinks no other drink but tears,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Brew'd with her sorrow, mesh'd upon her cheeks:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Speechless complainer, I will learn thy thought;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: In thy dumb action will I be as perfect
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As begging hermits in their holy prayers:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou shalt not sigh, nor hold thy stumps to heaven,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Nor wink, nor nod, nor kneel, nor make a sign,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But I of these will wrest an alphabet
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And by still practise learn to know thy meaning.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Young LUCIUS
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: Good grandsire, leave these bitter deep laments:
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: Make my aunt merry with some pleasing tale.
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Alas, the tender boy, in passion moved,

speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

string: Enter TITUS below
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Long have I been forlorn, and all for thee:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: How like the empress and her sons you are!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For well I wot the empress never wags
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But in her company there is a Moor;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And, would you represent our queen aright,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: It were convenient you had such a devil:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: What wouldst thou have us do, Andronicus?

string: DEMETRIUS

string: CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Look round about the wicked streets of Rome;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And when thou find'st a man that's like thyself.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Good Murder, stab him; he's a murderer.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Go thou with him; and when it is thy hap
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To find another that is like to thee,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Good Rapine, stab him; he's a ravisher.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Go thou with them; and in the emperor's court
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: There is a queen, attended by a Moor;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: for up and down she doth resemble thee:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: I pray thee, do on them some violent death;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: Well hast thou lesson'd us; this shall we do.
speaker: TAMORA

string: But would it please thee, good Andronicus,
speaker: TAMORA

string: To send for Lucius, thy thrice-valiant son,
speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

string: When he is here, even at thy solemn feast,
speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Marcus, my brother! 'tis sad Titus calls.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

Go, gentle Marcus, to thy nephew Lucius;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thou shalt inquire him out among the Goths:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Bid him repair to me, and bring with him
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Some of the chiefest princes of the Goths;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: This do thou for my love; and so let him,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: As he regards his aged father's life.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Nay, nay, let Rape and Murder stay with me;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: DEMETRIUS

string: TAMORA
speaker: TAMORA

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS

PUBLIUS
speaker: PUBLIUS

speaker: PUBLIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: PUBLIUS
speaker: PUBLIUS

speaker: PUBLIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Caius and Valentine, lay hands on them.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Exit
PUBLIUS,  & c. lay hold on CHIRON and DEMETRIUS
CHIRON
speaker: CHIRON

string: Villains, forbear! we are the empress' sons.
speaker: CHIRON

string: PUBLIUS
speaker: PUBLIUS

string: And therefore do we what we are commanded.
speaker: PUBLIUS

string: Stop close their mouths, let them not speak a word.
speaker: PUBLIUS

string: Is he sure bound? look that you bind them fast.
speaker: PUBLIUS

string: Re-enter TITUS, with LAVINIA; he bearing a knife, and she a basin
TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Come, come, Lavinia; look, thy foes are bound.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Sirs, stop their mouths, let them not speak to me;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: But let them hear what fearful words I utter.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: O villains, Chiron and Demetrius!
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Here stands the spring whom you have stain'd with mud,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: This goodly summer with your winter mix'd.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: You kill'd her husband, and for that vile fault
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Two of her brothers were condemn'd to death,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: My hand cut off and made a merry jest;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Both her sweet hands, her tongue, and that more dear
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Than hands or tongue, her spotless chastity,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Inhuman traitors, you constrain'd and forced.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: What would you say, if I should let you speak?
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Villains, for shame you could not beg for grace.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hark, wretches! how I mean to martyr you.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: This one hand yet is left to cut your throats,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Whilst that Lavinia 'tween her stumps doth hold
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: The basin that receives your guilty blood.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: You know your mother means to feast with me,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And calls herself Revenge, and thinks me mad:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Hark, villains! I will grind your bones to dust
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And with your blood and it I'll make a paste,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And of the paste a coffin I will rear
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And make two pasties of your shameful heads,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And bid that strumpet, your unhallow'd dam,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Like to the earth swallow her own increase.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: This is the feast that I have bid her to,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And this the banquet she shall surfeit on;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: For worse than Philomel you used my daughter,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And worse than Progne I will be revenged:
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And now prepare your throats. Lavinia, come,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: He cuts their throats
Receive the blood: and when that they are dead,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Let me go grind their bones to powder small
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And with this hateful liquor temper it;
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And in that paste let their vile heads be baked.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Come, come, be every one officious
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: To make this banquet; which I wish may prove
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: More stern and bloody than the Centaurs' feast.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: So, now bring them in, for I'll play the cook,
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: And see them ready 'gainst their mother comes.
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: Exeunt, bearing the dead bodies
SCENE III. Court of TITUS's house. A banquet set out.
Enter LUCIUS, MARCUS, and Goths, with AARON prisoner

speaker: LUCIUS

string: First Goth

string: LUCIUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS
speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

string: SATURNINUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: SATURNINUS

string: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: By uproar sever'd, like a flight of fowl
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Scatter'd by winds and high tempestuous gusts,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: This scatter'd corn  into one mutual sheaf,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: These broken limbs again into one body;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lest Rome herself be bane unto herself,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And she whom mighty kingdoms court'sy to,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Like a forlorn and desperate castaway,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Do shameful execution on herself.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: But if my frosty signs and chaps of age,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Grave witnesses of true experience,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Cannot induce you to attend my words,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: To LUCIUS
Speak, Rome's dear friend, as erst our ancestor,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: When with his solemn tongue he did discourse
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: To love-sick Dido's sad attending ear
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: The story of that baleful burning night
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: When subtle Greeks surprised King Priam's Troy,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tell us what Sinon hath bewitch'd our ears,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Or who hath brought the fatal engine in
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: That gives our Troy, our Rome, the civil wound.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: My heart is not compact of flint nor steel;
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Nor can I utter all our bitter grief,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: But floods of tears will drown my oratory,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And break my utterance, even in the time
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: When it should move you to attend me most,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lending your kind commiseration.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Your hearts will throb and weep to hear him speak.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Then, noble auditory, be it known to you,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That cursed Chiron and Demetrius
speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

string: Our father's tears despised, and basely cozen'd
speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

string: To beg relief among Rome's enemies:

string: Who drown'd their enmity in my true tears.

string: And oped their arms to embrace me as a friend.

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

string: Sheathing the steel in my adventurous body.

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: And make a mutual closure of our house.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Speak, Romans, speak; and if you say we shall,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Lo, hand in hand, Lucius and I will fall.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: AEMILIUS
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: Come, come, thou reverend man of Rome,
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: And bring our emperor gently in thy hand,
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: Lucius our emperor; for well I know
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: The common voice do cry it shall be so.
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: All
speaker: All

string: Lucius, all hail, Rome's royal emperor!
speaker: All

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Go, go into old Titus' sorrowful house,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: To Attendants
And hither hale that misbelieving Moor,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: To be adjudged some direful slaughtering death,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: As punishment for his most wicked life.
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Exeunt Attendants
LUCIUS, MARCUS, and the others descend
All
speaker: All

string: Lucius, all hail, Rome's gracious governor!
speaker: All

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Thanks, gentle Romans: may I govern so,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: To heal Rome's harms, and wipe away her woe!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: But, gentle people, give me aim awhile,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: For nature puts me to a heavy task:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Stand all aloof: but, uncle, draw you near,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: To shed obsequious tears upon this trunk.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: O, take this warm kiss on thy pale cold lips,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Kissing TITUS
These sorrowful drops upon thy blood-stain'd face,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: The last true duties of thy noble son!
speaker: LUCIUS

string: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Tear for tear, and loving kiss for kiss,
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Thy brother Marcus tenders on thy lips:
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: O were the sum of these that I should pay
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: Countless and infinite, yet would I pay them!
speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Come hither, boy; come, come, and learn of us
speaker: LUCIUS

string: To melt in showers: thy grandsire loved thee well:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Many a time he danced thee on his knee,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Sung thee asleep, his loving breast thy pillow:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Many a matter hath he told to thee,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Meet and agreeing with thine infancy;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: In that respect, then, like a loving child,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Shed yet some small drops from thy tender spring,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Because kind nature doth require it so:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Friends should associate friends in grief and woe:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Bid him farewell; commit him to the grave;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Do him that kindness, and take leave of him.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Young LUCIUS
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: O grandsire, grandsire! even with all my heart
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: Would I were dead, so you did live again!
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: O Lord, I cannot speak to him for weeping;
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: My tears will choke me, if I ope my mouth.
speaker: Young LUCIUS

string: Re-enter Attendants with AARON
AEMILIUS
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: You sad Andronici, have done with woes:
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: Give sentence on this execrable wretch,
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: That hath been breeder of these dire events.
speaker: AEMILIUS

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Set him breast-deep in earth, and famish him;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: There let him stand, and rave, and cry for food;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: If any one relieves or pities him,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: For the offence he dies. This is our doom:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Some stay to see him fasten'd in the earth.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: AARON
speaker: AARON

string: O, why should wrath be mute, and fury dumb?
speaker: AARON

string: I am no baby, I, that with base prayers
speaker: AARON

string: I should repent the evils I have done:
speaker: AARON

string: Ten thousand worse than ever yet I did
speaker: AARON

string: Would I perform, if I might have my will;
speaker: AARON

string: If one good deed in all my life I did,
speaker: AARON

string: I do repent it from my very soul.
speaker: AARON

string: LUCIUS
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Some loving friends convey the emperor hence,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And give him burial in his father's grave:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: My father and Lavinia shall forthwith
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Be closed in our household's monument.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: As for that heinous tiger, Tamora,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: No funeral rite, nor man in mourning weeds,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: No mournful bell shall ring her burial;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: But throw her forth to beasts and birds of prey:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Her life was beast-like, and devoid of pity;
speaker: LUCIUS

string: And, being so, shall have like want of pity.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: See justice done on Aaron, that damn'd Moor,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: By whom our heavy haps had their beginning:
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Then, afterwards, to order well the state,
speaker: LUCIUS

string: That like events may ne'er it ruinate.
speaker: LUCIUS

string: Exeunt
